questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following best describes pyronaridine?
questions.explanation:
Pyronaridine is an antimalarial agent. It is an erythrocyte schizonticide with high efficacy and 
mechanism of action similar to chloroquine. It is used in combination with artesunate.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in the retina?
questions.explanation:
Chloroquine has a large volume of distribution and is deposited in the retina. Long-term use of chloroquine results in retinopathy. The classical finding is 'bull’s-eye 
retinopathy'

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina. Whiff's 
test was positive and microscopy of the discharge is shown below. What is the drug of choice 
for this condition? 515 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
519 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario, a positive Whiff test and clue cells on microscopy point towards a diagnosis 
of bacterial vaginosis. Metronidazole (oral or intravaginal) or intravaginal clindamycin are 
considered the drugs of choice. The male partner should be treated in case of recurrent infections of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is best associated with lumefantrine?
questions.explanation:
Lumefantrine is an antimalarial agent. Lumefantrine is an orally active, high efficacy; long-acting erythrocytic schizonticide related 
structurally and acts similar to halofantrine. Lumefantrine is used only in combination with artemether.

questions.question: Question 5: Suramin is indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Suramin is primarily indicated in the treatment of African trypanosomiasis. It is indicated only in 
the early stages of African trypanosomiasis because of its limited entry across the blood-brain 
barrier. It has no clinical utility in American trypanosomiasis. Suramin has in vitro activity against 
retroviral reverse transcriptase but is ineffective in HIV infection.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presents with watery diarrhea, fever and abdominal pain. Investigations reveal a 
WBC count of 16,000 cells/microL. The patient has been on treatment with ampicillin for a 
few days. Which of the following antibiotics is approved for use in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The scenario is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile and 
fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic that is indicated as an alternative to vancomycin in severe 
and recurring Clostridium difficile infections. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis through the blockade of RNA polymerase.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following best describes tolnaftate?
questions.explanation:
Tolnaftate is a topical synthetic antifungal agent. It distorts the mycelial growth of yeast-like fungi and molds. It is effective in the treatment of 
dermatomycosis and tinea.

questions.question:
Question 8: A class of antibiotics that is clinically indicated in combination with penicillins is inactivated 
if combined with penicillins in the same solution before administration. Identify this class of 
drugs.
questions.explanation:
Aminoglycosides can be inactivated by various penicillins in vitro and thus should not be admixed 
in solution before administration. 520 
Sold by @itachibot Aminoglycosides and penicillin combination is indicated in several infections and they should not 
be admixed in the same solution before administration.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following antibiotics is not excreted through bile?
questions.explanation:
Gentamicin is not excreted through bile. It is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and aminoglycosides 
undergo minimum metabolism and are excreted almost entirely by the renal route. Erythromycin, cefoperazone, and rifampicin are excreted predominantly in bile.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
questions.explanation:
Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors. They competitively and reversibly interact with the enzyme sites to inhibit viral neuraminidase 
activity. This interferes with the release of the progeny from infected host cells, halting the spread 
of infection. Early administration hastens the resolution of symptoms if given within 48 h of infection. 
Oseltamivir is given at a dose of 75 mg, BD for 5 days for the treatment of Influenza A and B. For prophylaxis, it is given at a dose of 75mg, OD and continued for the duration of exposure.

questions.question: Question 11: Rifampicin can be used as first-line therapy in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin is the first-line therapy and is included in the regimens for both tuberculosis and 
leprosy. Doxycycline combined with rifampicin is considered a first-line agent for brucellosis.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in cornea?
questions.explanation:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to corneal opacity. Ocular toxicity of chloroquine: • Short-term therapy - blurring of vision and diplopia, reversible on stoppage of drug. • Long-term use (high-dose): • Keratopathy • Pigmentary retinopathy • Optic atrophy Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine. 521 
Sold by @itachibot Drugs causing corneal opacity: • Amiodarone • Phenothiazine • Indomethacin • Chloroquine Long-term treatment with these drugs can cause a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium 
called cornea verticillata. It is also seen in Fabry's disease.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis?

options.a: Aerobes have oxygen gradient inside the cell which deactivates metronidazole moiety
options.b: Only anaerobes and microaerophilic organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals
options.c: Aerobes have efflux drug pumping mechanism for metronidazole
options.d: Metronidazole inserts pore in the cell membrane of anaerobes and microaerophilic bacteria

questions.explanation:
Rifampicin is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis. It binds to the beta subunit of DNA dependent 
RNA-polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. The binding suppresses the chain 
formation in RNA synthesis. Option A: 5-Fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthesis. Option C: Nitrofurantoin produces highly reactive intermediates that cause DNA damage Option D: Novobiocin is a potent inhibitor of bacterial DNA gyrase. 522 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-Protozoal agents and Anthelmintic drugs
